repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Health Insurance Strategy for the
            Poor Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The US$90 million loan for the Health
            Insurance Strategy for the Poor Support Project for Ecuador
            was approved on February 16, 2006, signed on June 5, 2006
            and declared effective on June 6, 2006. There was some delay
            during the first weeks of project implementation, as a
            result of the lack of operational experience of the
            implementing agency and the imminent change of Government.
            The Borrower requested the first loan disbursement in the
            amount of US$1 million on December 24, 2006, just 20 days
            before the change of Government administration. Initial
            funds were allocated to finance some of the initial
            operational activities, mainly hiring of personnel. However,
            three weeks later, the new Administration decided not to
            start implementation of projects financed by the World Bank.
            On the sectoral side, one of the new administration's
            first actions was to dissolve the Secretaría Nacional de los
            Objetivos de Desarrollo del Milenio (National Secretariat
            for the Milenium Development Goals) (SODEM), which
            contributed to weakening the sectoral dialogue. A World Bank
            mission visited Ecuador in the beginning of March, 2007 to
            work with officials in the Ministry of Health (MOH), explore
            alternative options to implement the Project, introducing
            changes in its design, if necessary. The team organized a
            visit to Argentina with the new MOH insurance team to
            supervise the findings of a similar operation that was
            implemented in Argentina. However, the new Administration
            cancelled the trip and requested the cancellation of the
            Bank's loan. Due to the political context during that
            time, which led to the cancellation of loans for other
            Bank-financed projects, the Bank decided strategically to
            postpone its official response to gain time to find a
            solution to this matter and to re-establish dialogue with
            the new Government. The Government, however, maintained its
            position with respect to the projects financed by the Bank.
            A letter cancelling the US$1 million loan balance was sent
            to the Government on August 27, 2007. The Government of
            Ecuador (GOE) fully reimbursed the disbursed amount of
            US$1.0 million on January 9, 2008.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Health Insurance Strategy for the
            Poor Support (APL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Ecuador Health Insurance Strategy
            for the Poor Support (APL) Project helps provide health
            insurance coverage to targeted low-income groups in order to
            reduce infant, child, and maternal mortality, and reduce
            health inequalities between provinces and income levels. The
            project also aims to meet to change the operational culture
            of the health care systems by providing a new incentive
            framework that sets up new payment arrangements and takes a
            market approach to contracting for health services,
            promoting operational effectiveness, quality improvements
            and efficiency. The project should also set the correct
            incentives for enrollment, monitoring and service delivery.
            There are two project components. The first strengthens
            monitoring, evaluation, and the auditing capacity of the
            Universal Health Insurance Program (PROAUS). Component 2
            supports the implementation and development of the Health
            Insurance Strategy for the Poor through conditional
            transfers to the government.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Health Insurance Project :
            indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Among the main targets of the Health
            Insurance Project, indigenous peoples and ethnic minorities
            stand as important beneficiaries of the project, and, it is
            to this end, this Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) seeks to
            ensure compliance and accountability, through
            recommendations as follows. Health care services providers
            shall be provided adequate training, to include
            intercultural health care services networks, along with
            ambulatory services as may be required. The Ministry of
            Health services shall be integrated with traditional
            medicine networks in the micro-regions, in addition to local
            sites. Participatory approaches shall include
            representatives of both government and indigenous
            organizations, to promote the intercultural health care,
            through social assistance services. Research, and monitoring
            will be conducted on existing traditional medicine
            practices, their access and use, consistent with health care
            services provided. Communication awareness and promotion
            campaigns will be conducted, as will participatory
            monitoring of local organizations, to meet regularly and
            discuss the quality of service, and beneficiary
            satisfaction. Evaluation and grievance mechanisms will be in
            place to ensure compliance with these regulations.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Health Insurance Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Insurance Project in Ecuador,
            will increase coverage of health insurance within the first
            and second quintiles of the economy by the end of 2008. It
            is however recognized, that the increase in coverage could
            potentially lead to increased generation of healthcare
            wastes in health establishments supported by the project. To
            this end, regulations stipulate the adequate waste
            management practices, including infectious and special
            medical wastes. These regulations cover classification,
            segregation, storage, collection, transport, treatment, and
            final disposal for such wastes. In addition, regulations
            address monitoring criteria, and sanctions of non-compliance.

Ecuador - Health Insurance Project :
